page.title: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:George Berkeley.jpg|thumb|right|upright|George Berkeley]] '''''Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous''''', or simply '''''Three Dialogues''''', is a 1713 book on [[metaphysics]] and [[idealism]] written by [[George Berkeley]]. Taking the form of a dialogue, the book was written as a response to the criticism Berkeley experienced after publishing ''[[A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge]]''.{{cite journal| last=Turbayne| first=C. M.| authorlink=Colin Murray Turbayne| title=Berkeley's Two Concepts of Mind| journal=[[Philosophy and Phenomenological Research]]| volume=20| issue=1| date=September 1959| pages=85–92| jstor=2104957| doi=10.2307/2104957}}
Repr. in {{cite book| last1=Engle| first1=Gale| last2=Taylor| first2=Gabriele| title=Berkeley's Principles of Human Knowledge: Critical Studies| location=Belmont, CA| publisher=Wadsworth| year=1968| pages=24–33}} In this collection of essays, Turbayne's work comprised two papers that had been published in [[Philosophy and Phenomenological Research]]: * "Berkeley's Two Concepts of Mind" * C. Turbayne's reply to [https://www.jstor.org/pss/2105263 S.A. Grave "A Note on Berkeley's Conception of the Mind"] ([[Philosophy and Phenomenological Research]], 1962, vol. 22, No. 4). Three important concepts discussed in the ''Three Dialogues'' are [[perception|perceptual]] relativity, the conceivability/[[master argument]]{{efn|"master argument" was coined by André GalloisA. Gallois, [http://su-ltd.mylivepage.ru/file/2716/6135_Gallois_on_Berkeley.djvu "Berkeley's Master Argument."] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120714063318/http://su-ltd.mylivepage.ru/file/2716/6135_Gallois_on_Berkeley.djvu |date=2012-07-14 }} ''The Philosophical Review'' 83 (1974), pp. 55-69}} and Berkeley's [[phenomenalism]]. Perceptual relativity argues that the same object can appear to have different characteristics (e.g. shape) depending on the observer's [[Perspective (visual)|perspective]]. Since objective features of objects cannot change without an inherent change in the object itself, shape must not be an objective feature. ==Background== In 1709, Berkeley published his first major work, ''[[s:An Essay Towards a New Theory of Vision|An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision]]'', in which he discussed the limitations of human vision and advanced the theory that the proper objects of sight are not material objects, but light and colour.See {{Cite book |last=Berkeley |first=George |year=1709 |contribution= |title= An Essay Towards a New Theory of Vision |edition= 2 |publisher=Jeremy Pepyat |publication-date=1709 |publication-place=Dublin |page= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1o85AAAAcAAJ&dq=editions%3AdyOzLl2K0NEC&hl=bg&pg=PR1#v=onepage&q&f=true |accessdate=12 July 2014 }} via Google Books This foreshadowed his chief philosophical work, ''[[A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge]]'' (1710), which, after its poor reception, he rewrote into the ''Three Dialogues'' (1713). ==Hylas and Philonous== {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2018}} Berkeley's views are represented by Philonous (Greek: "lover of mind"), while [[Hylas]] (Greek: "matter") embodies the Irish thinker's opponents, in particular [[John Locke]]. In The First Dialogue, Hylas expresses his disdain for [[skepticism]], adding that he has heard Philonous to have "maintained the most extravagant opinion... namely, that there is no such thing as ''material substance'' in the world." Philonous argues that it is actually Hylas who is the skeptic and that he can prove it. Thus, a philosophical battle of wit begins. Philonous questions Hylas systematically regarding what humans know of the world, first examining secondary qualities, such as heat, to show that such qualities do not exist outside the individual mind. He then moves on to primary qualities such as extension and shape, and likewise argues that they, too, are dependent entirely on one's [[perception]] (e.g., From a distance, a great mountain appears to be small, and the shape of a thing may change dramatically under a microscope). Hylas's view of matter (which has its origin in the Platonic theory of forms [http://www.philosophypages.com/hy/2f.htm], or abstract entities that exist outside of the sensible world){{citation needed|date=October 2013}} is systematically destroyed by Philonous (Berkeley). The basic argument is that because matter is only known to us by its sensible qualities, it is impossible to describe or even imagine matter without these qualities. For in the absence of sensible qualities, matter, by definition, loses its essential qualities. Berkeley's argument goes further: sensible qualities are not inherent in matter. Rather, they are ascribed and understood by the mind. Color, sound, temperature and even shape are qualities entirely dependent on a mind. Indeed, without a "mind," it becomes impossible to imagine "matter." The answer to the question, "If a tree falls in the forest and no mind is present, does it make a noise?" is answered by Berkeley's immaterialism: There is no tree. However, God is always perceiving everything. In other words, there is ''always'' a mind present. A human (and thus a human mind) need not be present for the tree to make a sound, for the mind of God is always present, or so Berkeley argues. It is this mind of God that gives sensible qualities to matter, not matter itself. In his own time Berkeley faced opposition from many philosophers who held to the Platonic view. These philosophers thought Berkeley vulgar because his own view seemed to confirm the views held by the lower classes. Roughly speaking, the "common view" was that God created everything and that the things on earth were the real things. Some philosophers did not believe in God, and believed matter on earth was but an imitation of actual matter that existed in another dimension. Berkeley sided with the common view. The philosophy presented is often misinterpreted. The criticism is that Berkeley claims that we live in an illusory world, when in fact, Berkeley advocates for the acceptance of ideas as real "things." When we refer to an object, we don't refer to a material form, but to the idea of the object that informs our senses. Berkeley doesn't propose that ''nothing'' is real; he proposes that ''ideas themselves'' compose reality. ==See also== * [[Idealism]] * [[Master Argument]] * [[s:An Essay Towards a New Theory of Vision|''An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision'' (1709)]] * [[A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge|''A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge'' (1710)]] == Notes == {{Notelist}} == References == ==Further reading== * {{cite book |author= Stoneham, Tom |title= Berkeley’s World: An Examination of the Three Dialogues |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=GE_9nEm9PDYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Stoneham+%22Berkeley%E2%80%99s+World%22#v=onepage&q&f=false |publisher= Oxford University Press |location= Oxford|year= 2002|isbn= 0-19-875237-7}} ==External links== {{wikisource|Three Dialogues Between Hylas and Philonous}} * [http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/4724/pg4724.txt George Berkeley's ''Three Dialogues Between Hylas and Philonous''] At [[Project Gutenberg]] online TXT version * {{librivox book | title=Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous | author=BERKELEY}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060917030725/http://oregonstate.edu/instruct/phl302/reading/berkeley_ex.html Exercise Questions] from [[Oregon State University]] * [http://www.earlymoderntexts.com Contains ''Three Dialogues'', slightly modified for easier reading] * [https://archive.org/details/three_dialogues_0908_librivox Audiobook version of ''Three Dialogues Between Hylas and Philonous''] (Public domain) {{authoritycontrol}} [[Category:1713 books]] [[Category:Books by George Berkeley]] [[Category:Dialogues]] [[Category:Metaphysics literature]]

[[Image:Pas de quatre1845.jpg|thumb|300px|right|<center>Lithograph by A. E. Chalon of (left to right) [[Carlotta Grisi]], [[Marie Taglioni]], [[Lucille Grahn]] and [[Fanny Cerrito]] in ''Pas de Quatre'', 1845]]
The important place of '''women in dance''' can be traced back to the very origins of civilization. Cave paintings, Egyptian frescos, Indian statuettes, ancient Greek and Roman art and records of court traditions in China and Japan all testify to the important role women played in ritual and religious dancing from the start. In the [[Middle Ages]], what has become known as [[ballet]] had its beginnings in Italian court festivals when women frequently played the parts of men. It was however in late 17th-century France that the [[Paris Opera Ballet|Paris Opera]] produced the first celebrated ballerinas. While women began to dominate the ballet scene in the 18th century, it was with the advent of [[Romantic ballet]] in the 19th century that they became the undisputed centre of attraction with stars playing the leading roles in the works of [[Marius Petipa]], appearing in theatres across Europe from Milan's [[La Scala]] to the [[Mariinsky Theatre]] in Saint Petersburg. More recently, women have played a leading role in developing various forms of [[modern dance]] including [[flamenco]] and [[expressionist dance]].
==History== Women have always played a predominant role in dance, as can be seen from its earliest history until the emergence of formal dances in the 15th century which developed into [[ballet]].
===Antiquity=== Cave paintings from as long ago as 6000 BC provide scenes of dancing women. Examples can be seen in the [[Grotta dell'Addaura|Addauta Cave]] near [[Palermo]] and in the [[Roca dels Moros]] in [[Catalonia]]. In [[Ancient Egypt]], women performed ritual dances for religious ceremonies such as funerals, as illustrated by frescos on the pharaohs' tombs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reshafim.org.il/ad/egypt/timelines/topics/music.htm|title=Egyptia Dance and Music|publisher=Kibbutz Reshafim|accessdate=4 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> The oldest records of organised dance and of professional female dancers come from Egypt. Especially in the [[Old Kingdom of Egypt|Old Kingdom]], women were organised into groups known as [[khener]], apparently being joined by men only at a later stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raqssharqisociety.org/femaledanceancientegypt.pdf|title=Female Dance in Ancient Egypt|author=Patricia Spencer|publisher=The Raqs Shardi Society|accessdate=4 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
In the Indian subcontinent too, there is early evidence of dancing women, most notably a bronze statuette from [[Mohenjo-daro]] in the [[Indus Valley]] dating from around 2500 BC.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalmuseumindia.gov.in/prodCollections.asp?pid=44&id=1&lk=dp1|title=Pre-History & Archaeology|publisher=National Museum, Janpath, New Delhi|accessdate=4 April 2014 |language=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://webetab.ac-bordeaux.fr/Pedagogie/EPS/spip/IMG/pdf/les_grands_courants_danse.pdf|title=Les grands courants de la danse|author=Elisabeth Gouet|publisher=Académie de Bordeaux|accessdate=2 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref> While men's early participation in dancing rituals appears to have been connected to hunting and fighting, women's dance was above all related to fertility, both agricultural and human.<ref name=ml/>
<gallery class="center"> File:064 Pintures de la cova dels Moros, exposició al Museu de Gavà.JPG|Dancing women, El Cogul caves, Lérida File:Dancing girl.jpg|Dancing girl statuette from [[Mohenjo-daro]], 2500-1500 BC File:Female topless egyption dancer on ancient ostrakon.jpg|Ancient Egyptian dancer, c. 1200 BC File:Musicians and dancers on fresco at Tomb of Nebamun.jpg|Tomb of Nebamun c. 1400 BC </gallery>
Dance in [[Ancient Crete|classical Crete]] and [[Ancient Greece|Greece]] seems to have been influenced by the [[Dance and Dancers in Ancient Egypt|dances of Ancient Egypt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/849211/Western-dance/22101/Dance-in-Classical-Greece#toc22102|title=Dance in classical Greece|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=6 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> There are many examples of ancient Greek art from the 6th and 5th centuries BC depicting dancing women.<ref name=ml>{{cite web|url=http://www.cvm.qc.ca/mlandry/folklore/historiq.htm|title=La Danse au fil des âges|author=Michel Landry|publisher=CÉGEP du Vieux Montréal|accessdate=2 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref> The virgins of [[Delos]] danced in a circle to honour [[Apollo]]<ref name="Calame2001">{{cite book|last=Calame|first=Claude|title=Choruses of Young Women in Ancient Greece: Their Morphology, Religious Role, and Social Functions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DhfmgSz1eR4C&pg=PA35|date=1 January 2001|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7425-1525-3|pages=35–}}</ref> while [[Terpsichore]] was the [[Muse]] of dance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/588097/Terpsichore|title=Terpsichire|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=6 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> In the 6th century BC, the ''[[Greek chorus|choros]]'' became a lasting feature of Greek theatre while women known as the Dyonysiac, frequently depicted on Greek vases, dance in frensy, celebrating [[Dionysus]], the god of wine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyworld.net/wrldhis/plaintexthistories.asp?historyid=ab82|title=History of Dance: Dance and Music|publisher=History World|accessdate=4 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> In Ancient Rome, female singers and dancers performed in the annual celebrations of [[Isis]] which included mystery plays representing the resurrection of [[Osiris]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ic.galegroup.com/ic/suic/ReferenceDetailsPage/ReferenceDetailsWindow?displayGroupName=Reference&disableHighlighting=false&prodId=SUIC&action=e&windowstate=normal&catId=&documentId=GALE|title=Women in Ancient Music: Arts and Humanitites Through the Eras|author= Edward I. Bleiberg (ed)|publisher=Gale: Student Resources in Context|year=2005|accessdate=6 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Donkey head rhyton Louvre Cp3561 n2.jpg|Musician and dancer, Athens, 460 BC File:Tondo of a Kylix by the Brogos Painter.jpg|Greek dancing girl, 5th century BC File:Terracotta dancing maenad MET 12.232.13.png|Greek terracotta statuette of a dancing [[Maenad]], 3rd century BC File:Veiled dancer Louvre Myr660.jpg|Veiled dancer, terracotta, c. 100 BC File:Roman fresco Villa dei Misteri Pompeii 009.jpg|Fresco of [[Dionysus|Dionysic]] initiation dance, Pompei, c. 60 BC </gallery>
The Bible contains several accounts of women dancing, in particular the celebrations led by [[Miriam]] after the [[Crossing the Red Sea|crossing of the Red Sea]] when women are said to have danced and played hand-drums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/women-with-hand-drums-dancing-bible|title=Women with hand-drums, dancing: Bible|author=Carol Meyers|publisher=Jewish Women's Archive|accessdate=4 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> After [[David]] had returned from slaying [[Goliath]], women came out singing and dancing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biblehub.com/kjv/1_samuel/18-6.htm|title=1 Samuel 18:6|publisher=Bible Hub|accessdate=8 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> In the [[New Testament]], Matthew tells the story of how [[Salome]] danced for [[Herod the Great|Herod]] in order to be given the head of John the Baptist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=matthew%2014-14&version=NIV|title=John the Baptist Beheaded, Matthew 14-14|publisher=Bible Gateway|accessdate=6 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Miriams Tanz.jpg|Miriam's dance, Tomić Psalter, c. 1360 File:Dance of Salome.jpg|Dance of Salome, [[Robert Fowler (artist)|Robert Fowler]] (1885) </gallery>
===China and Japan=== In China too there is a long recorded history of women dancers since the [[Zhou Dynasty]] (c. 1046–256 BC) reaching a peak in the [[Tang Dynasty]] (618–907 AD).<ref name="aesthetic tradition">{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=d1eZuB2xwYwC&pg=PA5&f=false#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Chinese Aesthetic Tradition |author= Zehou Li |page=5 |publisher= University of Hawaii Press |others=translated by Maija Bell Samei |year= 2009 |isbn=978-0824833077 }}</ref> The chorus dances performed by women in the Zhou dynasty were known as ''xi''. The [[Chinese variety art|ancient theatrical spectacles]] called ''baixi'' probably involved dancing girls in dresses with fluttering silk sleeves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xip.fi/atd/china/the-early-history-of-chinese-theatre.html|title=The Early History of Chinese Theatre|publisher=Theatre Academy Helsinki|accessdate=6 April 2014 |isbn=978-952-9765-56-0|language=}}</ref> Texts from the [[Spring and Autumn period]] (771–476 BC) contain descriptions of professional dancing girls while the Nishang Yuyi dance, created by the Emperor [[Li Longji]] (685–762), stages virgin women dancing as if in a magic world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israeldance.co.il/toldot/articles/153|title=Dance History of China|author=Yaron Margolin|publisher=Israel Dance|accessdate=6 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> In 12th-century Japan, the [[Shirabyoshi]] were famous for their dancing and poetry. One of the most famous was the court dancer [[Shizuka Gozen|Shizuka]] who appears in the Japanese literature of the period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.immortalgeisha.com/history_01.php|title=History of the Geisha, Part One: 1100AD - 1750AD|publisher=Immortal Geisha|accessdate=9 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Dinastia_tang,_danzatrice_con_vestito_di_piume_e_gonna_ad_arcobaleno,_cina_del_nord,_710_ca._02.JPG|Chinese dancer from the Tang dynasty File:Sui Musikantinnen mit Tänzerin Museum Rietberg RCH 507.jpg|Statuettes of female musicians and a dancer, Sui dynasty (c. 600 AD) File:Danseuses Chine Guimet 291002.jpg|Dancing figures, Tang dynasty, 7th century File:Tang Dynasty Dancer.jpg|Female dancer from the Tang dynasty File:Met, female dancer, western han dynasty, 2nd century BC.JPG|Female dancer, Han dynasty File:Shizuka Gozen.jpg|Shizuka from 12th-century Japan
</gallery>
===Middle Ages=== In the [[Middle Ages]], with the spread of Christianity across Europe, the church generally frowned upon dance although there was often dancing at [[folk dance|folk festivals]], particularly at the beginning of May. In France and Italy, chain and circular dances such as the ''[[Carol (music)|carole]]'', and the ''tresque'' were popular from the 4th to 14th centuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lamarotte.fr/?page_id=586|title=Danses médiévales et renaissance|publisher=La Marotte|accessdate=6 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref> They were usually danced in a closed circle with men and women interspersed and holding hands.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mullally|first=Robert|title=The Carole: A Study of a Medieval Dance|location=Farnham, Surrey, England|publisher=Ashgate|year=2011|pages=41–50|isbn=978-1-4094-1248-9}}</ref> In Italy, the lively [[saltarello]] from Naples became popular in the 14th and 15th centuries. Groups of [[courtesan]]s dressed as men performed the dance at [[Masquerade ball|masquerade]]s.<ref name="Caroso1995">{{cite book|last=Caroso|first=Fabritio|title=Courtly Dance of the Renaissance: A New Translation and Edition of the Nobiltà Di Dame (1600)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PBwqMyKQvM4C&pg=PA43|year=1995|publisher=Courier Dover Publications|isbn=978-0-486-28619-8|pages=43–}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Meister des Rosenromans 001.jpg|Dancing the carole ([[Roman de la Rose]], c. 1250) File:Basse danse couleur.jpg|Medieval dance File:Pinelli Saltarello.JPG|Saltarello, illustrated by [[Bartolomeo Pinelli]] File:Valois Tapestry 2.jpg|Lavish ball held by [[Catherine de' Medici]] in 1573 </gallery>
==Emergence of ballet== In the 15th century, court festivities in Italy became ever more elaborate, often featuring formal dances. One of the early masters was [[Domenico da Piacenza]] (c. 1400–1470) who compiled a manual of dance: ''De arte saltandi et choreas ducendi''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbm.com/~lindahl/pnd/|title=De arte saltandi et choreas ducendi|publisher=pbm.com|accessdate=8 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> In France, too, professional dancing began to take shape when dancers performed for [[Henry III of France]] at [[Palace of Fontainebleau|Fontainebleau]] in the early 1580s. Further presentations were made for [[Louis XIII]], who frequently took the main part himself. But it was, above all, during the reign of [[Louis XIV]] (1643–1715) that the foundations were laid for what became known as ballet. The king not only had the rules of dance written down but established the [[Académie Royale de Danse]] in 1661, which developed into today's [[Paris Opera Ballet]].<ref name=ml/> Many of the early ballets were created by the Italian-French composer [[Jean Baptiste Lully]] and the French choreographer [[Pierre Beauchamp]], often assisted by [[Molière]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ccs.neu.edu/home/yiannis/dance/history.html|title=History of Ballet|publisher=Northeastern University|accessdate=8 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
Initially, female parts in the early ballets were taken by young men; but, in 1681, a young woman known as [[De Lafontaine|Mademoiselle De Lafontaine]] danced in Lully's ''Le Triomphe de l'amour''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/326306/La-Fontaine|title=La Fontaine |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=9 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> She went on to be the leading ballerina in at least 18 other productions at the Paris Opera between 1681 and 1693, establishing the supreme importance of women in ballet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100047735|title=Mlle de Lafontaine|publisher=Oxford Reference|accessdate=9 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> De Lafontaine was succeeded by [[Marie-Thérèse de Subligny]] who became the first ballerina to perform in London when she appeared with [[Claude Ballon]] in 1699.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100539716|title=Marie-Thérèse Subligny|publisher=Oxford Reference|accessdate=9 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Said to be the best ballerina of her day, with beautiful eyes and a fine figure, Subligny danced at the Paris Opera from 1688 until her retirement in 1707.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://operabaroque.fr/Cadre_baroque.htm|title=Le Triomphe de l'amour|publisher=Le magazine de l'opéra baroque|accessdate=9 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
The next leading dancer of the Opéra was [[Françoise Prévost]] (1680–1741), whose precision, lightness and grace contributed much to classical ballet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/475670/Francoise-Prevost|title=Françoise Prévost|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=9 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> She persuaded conductor [[Jean-Féry Rebel]] to compose suites specifically for ballet. His ''Caprice'', ''Boutade'', ''Les Caractères de la danse'' and ''La Terpsichore'' brought her considerable success. In particular, her personal interpretation of the steps in ''Caprice'' served as an example for other soloists while she transformed the ''Caractères'' into a sequence illustrating different types of lover, both male and female. Prévost trained two highly successful dancers, [[Marie-Anne de Cupis de Camargo|Marie Camargo]] (1710–1770) and [[Marie Sallé]] (1707–1756), who added their personal preferences to her ''Caractères'', each developing individual styles. They would take her place as [[prima ballerina]]s after she retired from the opera in 1730.<ref name="Brooks2007">{{cite book|last=Brooks|first=Lynn|title=Women’s Work: Making Dance in Europe Before 1800|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=By5TNdV4dGUC&pg=PA131|year=2007|publisher=Univ of Wisconsin Press|isbn=978-0-299-22530-8|pages=131–}}</ref><ref name="Greskovic2005">{{cite book|last=Greskovic|first=Robert|title=Ballet 101: A Complete Guide to Learning and Loving the Ballet|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2COs6yh_LS0C&pg=PA19|year=2005|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|isbn=978-0-87910-325-5|pages=19–}}</ref>
Camargo proved to be a tremendous success, not only as a result of her dazzling footwork (especially her [[entrechat|entrechat à quatre]]), but because she introduced slightly shorter skirts and new hair styles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/90467/Marie-Camargo|title=Marie Camargo|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=9 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> She also discarded high-heeled shoes, introducing dancing slippers which facilitated the execution of the more demanding routines.<ref name="Kassing2007">{{cite book|last=Kassing|first=Gayle|title=History of Dance: An Interactive Arts Approach|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_lLoTsT2X5EC&pg=PA113|year=2007|publisher=Human Kinetics|isbn=978-0-7360-6035-6|pages=113–}}</ref> By dancing demanding routines, which had previously been performed exclusively by men, Camargo further consolidated the image of the ballerina.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mtholyoke.edu/courses/nvaget/danseuse/ladanseuse/ladanseuse/1700-1750.html|title= La Danseuse : Evolution et Révolution: Les années 1700 à 1750: Les premières danseuses à l’Opéra|publisher=Mount Holyoke|accessdate=10 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
Sallé sought more from ballet than skillful demonstrations of technique as favoured by proponents of traditional ballet. She believed music, steps, decor and costumes should all contribute to a graceful, expressive performance combining [[pantomime]] with dance in what became known as [[ballet d'action]]. As many in the Paris Opera did not share her views, she decided to move to the more liberal London. At [[Royal Opera House|Covent Garden]], she caused a sensation in 1734 as Galatea in ''Pygmalion'', a ballet she had choreographed herself. Discarding the usual attire of a ballerina, she chose to wear a simple muslin tunic and allow her hair to fall freely over her shoulders.<ref name="Garfunkel2002">{{cite book|last=Garfunkel|first=Trudy|title=On Wings of Joy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GyTwwDm3YT4C&pg=PA20|year=2002|publisher=E-reads/E-rights|isbn=978-0-7592-2862-7|pages=20–}}</ref> The following year, she even decided to dress as a man while performing the role of Cupid but the reviews were extremely critical. As a result, she returned to Paris where she danced at the Opéra until her retirement in 1740 at the young age of 33. Thereafter, she occasionally danced for the court at [[Château de Versailles|Versailles]].<ref name="Brooks2007"/>
During the second half of the 18th century, the dominating star of the Paris Opera was [[Marie-Madeleine Guimard]] who may not have had the technique of Sallé but was nevertheless recognized for her sensuous movements, her numerous suitors and her exotic attire. Other stars included [[Marie Allard]] (1738–1802) who joined the Paris Opera in 1756 where she was trained by [[Gaétan Vestris]], becoming not just an étoile but also his wife. Although she was rather corpulent and frequently pregnant, she was acclaimed for her impressive footwork.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mtholyoke.edu/courses/nvaget/danseuse/ladanseuse/ladanseuse/1750-1830.html|title=La Danseuse: Evolution et Révolution: Les années 1750 à 1830|publisher=Mount Holyoke|accessdate=11 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Marie-Thérèse de Subligny.jpg|[[Marie-Thérèse de Subligny]] (c. 1700) File:Jean Raoux - Mademoiselle Prévost as a Bacchante.jpg|[[Françoise Prévost]] (c. 1723) File:CamargoLancret.jpg|[[Marie Camargo]] painted by Nicolas Lancret (c. 1730) File:MarieSalle.jpg|[[Marie Sallé]] (c. 1730) File:Mademoiselle Guimard as Terpsichore, by Jacques-Louis David.jpg|[[Marie-Madeleine Guimard]] (c. 1774) </gallery>
==Romantic ballet== The most successful period for female ballet dancers was around the 1830s and 1840s when they became the great stars of [[Romantic ballet]]. The Italian-Swedish [[Marie Taglioni]] (1804–1884) not only excelled at the Paris Opera when she danced ''[[La Sylphide]]'' in 1832 but extended her fame to Saint Petersburg's [[Mariinsky Ballet]] as well as to the stages of Berlin, Milan and London until her retirement in 1847. It was she who developed ballet's [[en pointe]] (dancing on the tips of the toes) while introducing new fashions in dress and hair styling which became popular throughout Europe. The Austrian [[Fanny Elssler]] (1810–1884) gained fame and fortune by dancing the flirtatious Spanish [[cachucha]] in ''Le Diable boiteux'', performing not only in Austria, Germany, France, England and Russia but also in the United States. Nevertheless, in 1845 she refused to dance with her rivals Marie Taglioni, [[Carlotta Grisi]], [[Fanny Cerrito]], and [[Lucile Grahn]] in [[Jules Perrot]]'s ''[[Pas de Quatre]]''.<ref name=vam>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/r/romantic-ballet/|title=Romantic Ballet|publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum|accessdate=16 April 2014|language=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mtholyoke.edu/courses/nvaget/danseuse/ladanseuse/ladanseuse/1830-1848.html|title=La Danseuse: Evolution et Révolution: Les années 1830 à 1848:La danse romantique|publisher=Mount Holyoke|accessdate=16 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
Presented at [[Her Majesty's Theatre]] in London, the ''Pas de Quatre'' caused a sensation, bringing together the four greatest ballerinas of the day. In addition to Marie Taglioni, Italy's Grisi (1819–1899) had become famous both in Paris and Saint Petersburg for her ''[[Giselle]]'', while Cerrito from Naples had become the star of [[La Scala]] in Milan. Grahn (1819–1907), a Dane trained by Bournonville, was based in Paris but had also danced in London, Saint Petersburg and Milan before settling in Germany.<ref name=vam/>
<gallery class="center"> File:Marie-taglioni-in-zephire.jpg|[[Marie Taglioni]] in ''Zephire et Flore'' (c. 1831) File:Elssler Cachucha.jpg|[[Fanny Elssler]] in ''La Cachucha'' (1836) File:Giselle -Carlotta Grisi -1841 -2.jpg|[[Carlotta Grisi]] in ''Giselle'' (1841) File:Vivandiere -Kathi -Fanny Cerrito -London -1844.jpg|[[Fanny Cerrito]] in ''La Vivandière'' (1844) File:Lucille grahn.jpg|[[Lucile Grahn]] in ''La Cachucha'' (1838) File:Pauline Leroux in François Benoist's Le Diable amoureux.jpg|[[Pauline Leroux]] in ''[[Le Diable amoureux (ballet)|Le Diable Amoureux]]'' (1840) </gallery>
Several notable Italian ballerinas emerged in the second half of the 19th century, reaching their zeniths in Russia. Italian-born [[Virginia Zucchi]] (1849–1933) first danced in Italy and Germany but her interpretations of [[Marius Petipa]]'s ballet in Russia were so successful that the Tzar insisted she should join the [[Mariinsky Ballet]] in Saint Petersburg. In the mid-1880s, she starred in ''[[Coppélia]]'', ''[[La fille mal gardée]]'' and ''[[La Esmeralda (ballet)|La Esmeralda]]'', revolutionizing ballet in Russia through the extraordinary power of her performances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803133549548|title=Virginia Zucchi|publisher=Oxford Index|accessdate=17 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Pierina Legnani]] (1863–1930) from Milan followed as similar path, also dancing at the Mariinsky from 1892 where she originated famous roles in Petipa's ballets including ''[[Cinderella (Fitinhof-Schell)|Cinderella]]'', ''[[Swan Lake]]'' and ''[[Raymonda]]'', gaining the title of [[prima ballerina assoluta]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100058642|title=Pierina Legnani|publisher=Oxford Reference|accessdate=17 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Carlotta Brianza]] (1867–1930), also from Milan, first gained fame at [[La Scala]] with which she toured the United States. She is remembered above all for dancing Aurora at the premiere of Petipa's ''[[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|Sleeping Beauty]]'' in 1890.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095526796|title=Carlotta Brianza|publisher=Oxford Index|accessdate=17 April 2014 |language=}}</ref><ref name="PraaghBrinson1963">{{cite book|last1=Praagh|first1=Peggy Van|last2=Brinson|first2=Peter|title=The choreographic art: an outline of its principles and craft|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g7I3AQAAIAAJ|year=1963|publisher=Knopf}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Esmeralda -Virginia Zucchi -1886.JPG|[[Virginia Zucchi]] in ''La Esmeralda'' (1886) File:Legnani-whitepearl.jpg|[[Pierina Legnani]] in ''La Perle'' (1896) File:Brianza-Esmeralda.jpg|[[Carlotta Brianza]] in ''La Esmeralda'' (c. 1890) </gallery>
==20th-century ballet== New, more dynamic approaches to ballet developed from the beginning of the 20th century, the most influential being [[Sergei Diaghilev]]'s [[Ballets Russes]], promoting innovative collaborations between choreographers, composers and dancers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history-and-heritage/ART309940|title= Diaghilev's Golden Age of the Ballets Russes dazzles London with V&A display|author=Kirstie Brewer|publisher=Culture24|date=13 October 2010|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> One of the early stars was [[Anna Pavlova]] (1881–1931) who gained fame by dancing ''[[The Dying Swan]]'' choreographed by [[Mikhail Fokine]] before joining the Ballets Russes in 1909.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russianballethistory.com/annapavlovathelegend.htm|title=The Legendary Anna Pavlova|publisher=Russian Ballet History|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Her rival, [[Tamara Karsavina]] (1885–1978), who also performed with the Ballets Russes, is remembered above all for creating the title role in Fokine's ''[[The Firebird]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russianballethistory.com/diaghilevsdancers.htm|title=Diaghilev's dancers|publisher=Russian Ballet History|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Olga Spessivtseva]] (1895–1991) danced with the Mariinsky in Saint Petersburg but also toured with the Ballets Russes, dancing Aurora in Diaghilev's ''The Sleeping Princess'' (1921) in London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://etoiledelopera.e-monsite.com/pages/etoile-femme-de-1900-a-1929/olga-spessivtseva.html|title=Olga Spessivtseva |publisher=Les étoiles de l'Opéra de Paris|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Anna Pavlova 1912.jpg|[[Anna Pavlova]] (1912) File:Tamara Karsavina Petrushka 1911.jpg|[[Tamara Karsavina]] (1911) File:Olga Spessiva in Swan Lake costume, 1934 photographer Sydney Fox Studio, 3rd Floor, 88 King St, Sydney.jpg|[[Olga Spessivtseva]] (1934) </gallery>
Ballet also began to develop in London, thanks mainly to the efforts of two women. Polish-born [[Marie Rambert]] (1888–1982) who had also gained experience with the Ballets Russes founded the [[Ballet Club]] (later the Rambert Dance Company) in 1926 introducing new choreographers such as [[Frederick Ashton]]. Even more influential, [[Ninette de Valois]] (1898–2001) spent three years with the Ballets Russes before creating London's [[Vic-Wells Ballet]] in 1931 (later becoming the Royal Ballet) where [[Alicia Markova]] (1910–2004) was the first prima ballerina, starring in ballets from the Mariinsky's classical productions. Markova left to form her own touring company in 1937. Ten years later [[Margot Fonteyn]] (1919–1991) became the company's prima ballerina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/e/establishment-of-british-ballet/|title=The Establishment of British Ballet|publisher=V&A|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> The height of her fame came in 1961 when she embarked on a partnership with [[Rudolf Nureyev]], first in ''[[Giselle]]'', until she retired in 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nureyev.org/rudolf-nureyev-biography-margot-fonteyn/|title=Rudolf Nureyev and Margot Fonteyn, the perfect partnership|publisher=Rudolf Nureyev Foundation|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Ballet Goes To the Factory- Dance and Entertainment Organised by the Council For the Encouragement of Music and the Arts, England, 1943 D14038.jpg|[[Marie Rambert]], centre (1943) File:Ninette de Valois, 1914.jpg|[[Ninette de Valois]] (1914) File:Alicia Markova.jpg|[[Alicia Markova]] (1940) File:Margot Fonteyn Cinderella 1957.jpg|[[Margot Fonteyn]] (1957) </gallery>
As ballet developed in the United States, [[Maria Tallchief]] (1925–2013), the first major American prima ballerina, was promoted by the choreographer [[Bronislava Nijinska]] (1891–1972) when she joined the [[Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo]] in New York in 1942. She danced as a soloist in [[George Balanchine]]'s arrangements for ''[[Song of Norway]]'' in 1944. As Balanchine's wife, she soon became the star of the [[New York City Ballet]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/13/arts/dance/maria-tallchief-brilliant-ballerina-dies-at-88.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|title=Maria Tallchief, a Dazzling Ballerina and Muse for Balanchine, Dies at 88|author=Jack Anderson|newspaper=New York Times|date=12 April 2013|accessdate=24 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Lucia Chase]] (1897–1986) was a co-founder of the [[American Ballet Theatre]] in 1939 and became its artistic director for over 40 years, overseeing the production of a wide variety of new ballets.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/01/19/arts/dance-view-lucia-chase-helped-create-the-ballet-world-we-know.html|title=Dance View: Lucia Chase Helped Create the Ballet World we Know|author=Anna Kisselgoff|newspaper=New York Times|date=19 January 1986|accessdate=24 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Several outstanding American ballerinas have emerged over the years including [[Gelsey Kirkland]] (born 1952), who performed the leading role in ''[[The Firebird]]'' when she was just 17,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/gelsey-kirkland-9365803#controversy-and-comeback&awesm=~oCmUgMJASHMm00|title=Gelsey Kirkland|publisher=Biography.com|accessdate=24 April 2014|language=}}</ref> and [[Suzanne Farrell]] (born 1945) who was the star of Balanchine's ''[[Don Quixote (ballet)|Don Quixote]]'' in 1965.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.achievement.org/autodoc/page/far0bio-1|title=Suzanne Farrell Biography|publisher=Academy of Achievement|accessdate=24 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo Nutcracker 1940.JPG|[[Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo]], ''Nutcracker'' (1940) File:Maria Tallchief 1954.png|[[Maria Tallchief]] (1954) File:Suzanne Farrell 1965.jpg|[[Suzanne Farrell]] (1965) </gallery>
==Other forms of dance== [[File:Flamenco dancer 3467.jpg|thumb|200px|Flamenco dancer]] Women have also contributed significantly to most other forms of dance, in particular [[flamenco]], [[modern dance]], [[expressionist dance]], [[belly dance]] and [[cabaret]] which led to [[musical theatre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artsalive.ca/en/dan/dance101/forms.asp|title=Dance Forms: An Introduction |publisher=ArtsAlive.ca|accessdate=17 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
===Flamenco=== Flamenco music originated in the south of Spain in the 15th century, probably resulting from the influence of the Moors with possible origins in India. While many of the singers who emerged in the 18th century were men, women increasingly gained fame as dancers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andalucia.org/es/flamenco/evolucion-etapa-hermetica-primeros-cantaores/|title=Flamenco: Evolución. Etapa Hermética. Primeros cantaores|publisher=Andalucía.org|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=Spanish}}</ref> One of the earliest was [[Juana la Macarrona]] (1860–1947) who first performed in Seville with singer [[Silverio Franconetti]] but soon become popular not only throughout Spain but across Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nyoflamenco.es/index.php/aula-flamenca/artistas/baile/509-la-macarrona|title=La Macarrona|publisher=Noticias y Ocio|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=Spanish}}</ref> [[Lola Flores]] (1923–1995) is remembered for singing and dancing Andalusian folklore, especially flamenco, [[copla (music)|copla]] and [[chotis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andalucia.com/history/people/lolaflores.htm|title=Lola Flores|publisher=Andalucia.com|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Angelita Vargas]] (born 1946) is considered to be one of the greatest stars of Andalusian flamenco dancing, touring Europe, the United States, Japan and Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apsaraflamenco.fr/Angelita-Vargas.html?lang=fr|title=Angelita Vargas|publisher=Apsâra Flamenco|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
===Modern dance=== Led by women, various styles of [[modern dance]] began to develop towards the end of the 19th century. [[Loie Fuller]] (1862–1928) from Chicago was one of the pioneers. She employed her own natural approach to movement and improvisation, later becoming a star at the [[Folies Bergères]] in Paris.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artsalive.ca/en/dan/meet/bios/artistDetail.asp?artistID=168|title=Loie Fuller|publisher=Dance: National Arts Centre|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Inspired by Greek art, [[Isadora Duncan]] (1877–1927) from San Francisco paved the way to the modern free dance style believing it was more important to express the essence of life through movement rather than to follow the precepts of classical ballet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mdc.edu/wolfson/academic/ArtsLetters/art_philosophy/Humanities/beginnings/beginnings_of_modern_dance.htm|title=The Beginnings of Modern Dance|publisher=Miami Dade College|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Raised on a farm in New Jersey, [[Ruth St. Denis]] (1879–1968) developed her own interpretations of Oriental dance as an expression of spiritualism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.danceheritage.org/treasures/stdenis_essay_hecht.pdf|title=Ruth St. Denis (1879—1968): America's Divine Dancer |publisher=Dance Heritage Coalition|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> The American [[Martha Graham]] (1894–1991) exerted considerable influence on the development of modern dance through her New York-based [[Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095902861|title=Martha Graham|publisher=Oxford Reference|accessdate=20 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Other female figures who contributed to developments in the mid-20th century include [[Doris Humphrey]] (1895–1958) who choreographed Afro-American spirituals and [[Helen Tamiris]] (1905–1966) who played an important part in choreographing early musicals.<ref name="HendersonStacey2014">{{cite book|last1=Henderson|first1=Lol|last2=Stacey|first2=Lee|title=Encyclopedia of Music in the 20th Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m8W2AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA41|year=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-92946-6|pages=41–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/tamiris-helen|title=Helen Tamaris|author=Pauline Tish|publisher=Jewish Women's Archive|accessdate=20 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Another major choreographer of Broadway musicals was German-born [[Hanya Holm]] (1893–1992), a student of Mary Wigman.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/11/04/theater/hanya-holm-is-dead-at-99-influential-choreographer.html|title=Hanya Holm Is Dead at 99; Influential Choreographer|author=Jennifer Dunning|newspaper=New York Times|date=4 November 1992|accessdate=20 April 2014|language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Loie Fuller cph.3b32370.jpg|[[Loie Fuller]] (1896) File:Isadora Duncan 1903.jpg|[[Isadora Duncan]] (1903) File:Ruth St. Denis in Black and Gold Nautch (Hartsook Photo).jpg|[[Ruth St. Denis]] (1916) File:Martha Graham 1948.jpg|[[Martha Graham]] (1948) </gallery>
===Expressionist dance=== The German [[Mary Wigman]] is credited as the creator of [[expressionist dance]]. Inspired by Oriental percussion, she often stressed the macabre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theatre-dance.cahss.ualr.edu/waynesweb/Expressionism/ExpressionisticDance.htm|title=Expressionistic Dance: Mary Wigman|publisher=Twentieth Century Dance|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Hertha Feist]] (1896–1990), also from Germany, was an expressionist dancer and choreographer. She established her own school in Berlin, combining gymnastics with nudism and dance although her ambitions were later seriously curtailed by the Nazis.<ref name=fmp>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-kultur.de/tanz/feist2.htm|title=Feist|author=Frank-Manuel Peter|publisher=SK Stiftung Kultur|accessdate=19 February 2014 |language=German}}</ref> Also an associate of Wigman, [[Gret Palucca]] (1902–1993) opened her own schools in Germany in the 1920s and 1930s but they were later closed because of her Jewish ancestry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adk.de/de/archiv/archivbestand/darstellende-kunst/kuenstler/Gret_Palucca.htm|title=Gret Palucca|publisher=Akademie der Künste|accessdate=19 April 2014 |language=German}}</ref> One of her students, [[Dore Hoyer]] (1911–1967), who was also an associate of Mary Wigman, developed her own programmes before the [[Second World War]] in Germany, the Netherlands, Denmark and Sweden. After the war she became ballet director at the [[Hamburg State Opera]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-kultur.de/tanz/hoyer.htm|title=Dore Hoyer (1911-1967)|publisher=SK Stiftung Kultur|accessdate=19 April 2014 |language=German}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-P047336, Berlin, Mary Wigman-Studio.jpg|[[Mary Wigman]] (1959) File:Genja Jonas - Gret Palucca 1930er-Jahre.jpg|[[Gret Palucca]] (1930s) File:Hoyer, Dore.jpg|[[Dore Hoyer]] </gallery>
===Belly dance=== While belly dancing appears to have its origins in the distant past, it was introduced to Europe and North America towards the end of the 19th century. Several of Egypt's film actresses performed belly dancing in the musicals of the 1930s and 1940s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aleenah.com/history.html|title=Bellydance Unveiled: A Brief History|publisher=Aleenah.com|accessdate=20 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Early stars included [[Tahia Carioca]] (1919–1999), [[Samia Gamal]] (1924–1994) and [[Nelly Mazloum]] (1929–2003).<ref name="Hammond2007">{{cite book|last=Hammond|first=Andrew|title=Popular Culture in the Arab World: Arts, Politics, and the Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O06bOHRW7s8C&pg=PA192|year=2007|publisher=American Univ in Cairo Press|isbn=978-977-416-054-7|pages=192–}}</ref> From the 1960s, belly dance became increasingly popular across the United States with stars including [[Dalilah (bellydancer)]] (1936–2001), Dahlena and [[Serena Wilson|Serena]] (1933–2007).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellydance.org/articles/bellydance_history.html|title=Belly Dance History ~ An American Odessey: A History of Modern US Bellydance|author=Helen Waldie|publisher=IAMED|accessdate=20 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Egyptian dancing girl.jpg|Egyptian belly dancer, [[World's Columbian Exposition|Chicago World Fair]] (1893) File:Tahyea05.jpg|[[Tahia Carioca]] (1920) File:Dalilah bailando danza oriental con crótalos.jpg|[[Dalilah (bellydancer)]] (1963) File:Randa Kamel Egyptian Bellydancer 2007 1.jpg|Randa Kamel, Cairo (2007) File:Rachel Brice 1 DSC 0126.jpeg|[[Rachel Brice]], Rennes (2012) </gallery>
===Cabaret=== Women started to sing and dance in the cabarets of Paris in the 1890s, emphasizing the female body by introducing seductive movements highlighting their breasts and hips. Most of them had no formal training, the exception being [[Cléo de Mérode]] (1875–1966) who left the Paris Opera to perform at the [[Folies Bergère]].<ref name=be>{{cite web|url=https://www.mtholyoke.edu/courses/nvaget/danseuse/ladanseuse/ladanseuse/1890-1914.html|title=La Danseuse: Evolution et Révolution: Les années 1890 à 1914: La Belle Epoque|publisher=Mount Holyoke|accessdate=21 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> The major choreographer was Algerian-born [[Mariquita (dancer)|Mariquita]] (1830–1922) who became ballet director at the Folies Bergère and the [[Opéra Comique]]. Stars of the period included the Spanish [[La Belle Otero]] from [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] who gained fame at Charles Franconi's [[Cirque d'été]] in 1890,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.histoire-image.org/site/etude_comp/etude_comp_detail.php?i=1140|title=La Belle Otero, emblème de la Belle Époque|publisher=Histoire par l'image|accessdate=21 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref> [[Émilienne d’Alençon]] (1869–1946) who danced at the Folies Bergère, and Dutch-born [[Mata Hari]] (1876–1917) who from 1905 became famous for her Indonesian-inspired temple dance, first in Paris and then in other European capitals.<ref name=be/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/mata-hari-9402348#exotic-dancer-and-mistress&awesm=~oCbYeBl3Wuhvzz|title=Mata Hari: Spy, Dancer (1876–1917)|publisher=bio.|accessdate=22 April 2014|language=}}</ref> [[La Goulue]] (1866–1929) is remembered for dancing the [[cancan]] at the [[Moulin Rouge]] in the 1890s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.appl-lachaise.net/appl/article.php3?id_article=1955|title=Weber Louise, dit La Goulue (1866-1929)|publisher=Amis et Passionnés du Père-Lachaise|accessdate=22 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Toulouse-Lautrec Folies-Bergère Emilienne d’Alençon and Mariquita.jpg|[[Mariquita (dancer)|Marquita]] and [[Émilienne d’Alençon]] (1893) File:Cléo de Mérode 02.jpg|[[Cléo de Mérode]] (c. 1897) File:La Belle Otero.jpg|[[La Belle Otero]] (c. 1905) File:Mata Hari 2.jpg|[[Mata Hari]] (1906) File:La Goulue01.jpg|[[La Goulue]] (c. 1890) </gallery>

{{Infobox person | image =Yolande Moreau étoiles d'or.jpg | caption =Moreau in 2009 | name = Yolande Moreau | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|02|27|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Brussels]], Belgium | yearsactive = 1981–present | occupation = Actress, comedian, director, screenwriter | children = 2 }} '''Yolande Moreau''' (born 27 February 1953) is a Belgian comedian, actress, [[film director]] and [[screenwriter]]. She has won three [[César Awards]] from four nominations. ==Life and career== Moreau has won three [[César Awards]]: one for Best First Film (in 2005) and two for Best Actress (in 2005 and 2009). She has more awards than any other Belgian actress. She made her cinematic debut with director [[Agnès Varda]] in two movies: Sept pièces (1984) and [[Vagabond (film)|Vagabond]] (1985). In 1989, she joined [[Jérôme Deschamps]] and [[Macha Makeieff]]'s troupe, of which she became one of the stars, especially on the TV programme, ''[[Les Deschiens]]''. She played La Levaque in [[Germinal (1993 film)|Germinal]] (1993) directed by [[Claude Berri]], a [[concierge]] in the film ''[[Amélie]]'' (2001) and Mama Chow in ''[[Micmacs (film)|Micmacs]]'' (2009) (both directed by [[Jean-Pierre Jeunet]]), a mime in ''[[Paris, Je T'aime]]'' (2006) and a lovesick woman in ''[[Vagabond (film)|Vagabond]]'' (1985) directed by [[Agnès Varda]]. She made her directorial debut with the movie [[When the Sea Rises]], which she co-wrote and starred in. The movie was acclaimed by critics, and Yolande Moreau won two [[César Awards]] for Best Debut and Best Actress. Moreau stars in the French horror thriller film ''[[La Meute|The Pack]]'', which premiered at the [[2010 Cannes Film Festival]].[http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/37479/the-pack-too-crazed-cannes The Pack Too Crazed for Cannes?] Her 2013 film ''[[Henri (2013 film)|Henri]]'' was screened in the [[Directors' Fortnight]] section at the [[2013 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.fr/en/readResonnances/59683.html |title=List of films in Cannes Directors' Fortnight |date=24 May 2013|accessdate=24 May 2013|work=Cannes}} On 10 June 2017, she was the guest of honor at the [[Brussels Film Festival]].http://www.lalibre.be/culture/cinema/le-festival-de-bruxelles-fait-la-fete-a-yolande-moreau-59392bdbcd700225434c5103http://bx1.be/news/le-brussels-film-festival-a-fait-la-fete-a-yolande-moreau/ == Theater == {| class="wikitable" ! | observatory = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = | floor_area = | seating_type = | seating_capacity = | elevator_count = | main_contractor = | architect = | architecture_firm = Livingston Slone Architects | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = | designations = | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_awards = | parking = | url = | embedded = | references = }} The '''Yupiit Piciryarait Cultural Center''' ('''YPCC'''), also known as ''Yupiit Piciryarait Cultural Center and Museum'', formerly known as the ''Yup'ik Museum, Library, and Multipurpose Cultural Center'' (or ''Facility''), is a non-profit [[cultural center]] of the [[Yup'ik]] (and sometimes [[Alaskan Athabaskan]] of the region) culture centrally located in [[Bethel, Alaska]] near the [[University of Alaska Fairbanks]]' Kuskokwim Campus and city offices.<ref name="heritagecenter2005">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnewbeck.com/pdf/ykdelta/AVCP/Yukon-Kusko_Heritage_Cntr_report.pdf|format=PDF|title=Yukon Kuskokwim Heritage Center Research Paper|publisher=Agnewbeck.com|accessdate=17 November 2014|date=July 2005}}</ref><ref name="tuzzypiciryarait">{{cite web|url=http://ttip.tuzzy.org/collect/ttimes/index/assoc/HASH2c29.dir/doc27.pdfformat=PDF|title= Yup'iit Piciryarait Cultural Center dedicated in Bethel|publisher=Ttip.tuzzy.org|accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> The center is a unique facility that combines a [[museum]], a [[library]], and multi-purpose cultural activity center including performing arts space, for cultural gatherings, feasts, celebrations, meetings and classes.<ref name="tuzzypiciryarait"/> and that celebrates the Yup'ik culture and serves as a regional cultural center for [[Southwest Alaska]].<ref name="livingstonslone">{{cite web|url=http://livingstonslone.com/portfolio/yupiit-piciryarait-museum-bethel/|title=Yup'iit Piciryarait Museum, Bethel|publisher=Livingstonslone.com=|accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> The name of ''Yupiit Piciryarait'' means "Yup'iks' customs" in [[Yup'ik language]] and derived from ''piciryaraq'' meaning "manner; custom; habit; tradition; way of life"<ref name="yupeskdict">{{cite web|url=http://www.uaf.edu/anla/collections/search/resultDetail.xml?id=CY972J2012|title=Resource Details - Alaska Native Language Archive|publisher=Uaf.edu|accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> Construction of this cultural facility was completed in 1995, funded through a State appropriation of federal funds. Total cost for construction was $6.15 million.<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/> The center was jointly sponsored by the Association of Village Council Presidents (AVCP) and the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF)<ref name="tuzzypiciryarait"/> and at the present the center operated by the UAF's Kuskokwim Campus, AVCP and City of Bethel.<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/> The building houses three community resources: the Consortium Library, the Yup'ik Museum, and the Multi-purpose room or [[auditorium]].<ref name="missionarea"/> The mission of the center is promote, preserve and develop the traditions of the Yup'ik through traditional and non-traditional art forms of the [[Alaska Native art]], including arts and crafts, performance arts, education, and Yup'ik language. The center also supports local artists and entrepreneurs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bethelculturalcenter.com/|title=YPCC|publisher=Bethelculturecenter.com|accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref>
==Architecture== The Yupiit Piciryarait Cultural Center was built in 1994‐95 to be a community and regional asset.<ref name="missionarea">{{cite web|url=http://www.alaska.edu/facilities/formats/YPCC-MAA-SON-Final.pdf|format=PDF|title=Mission Area Analysis and Statement of Need for Yupiit Piciryarait Cultural Center Programs at University of Alaska Fairbanks, Kuskokwim Campus in Bethel, Alaska|publisher=Alaska.edu|accessdate=17 November 2014|date=August 2013}}</ref> The [[architecture|architectural]] design of the facility celebrates the Yup'ik culture and designed by Livingston Slone Architects of [[Anchorage, Alaska|Anchorage]].<ref name="tuzzypiciryarait"/> In keeping with the preservation and conservation of the Yup'ik culture, Yup'ik themes such as the double circle motif or circle-and-dot design (''ellanguaq'' <small>sg</small> ''ellanguat'' <small>pl</small> in Yup'ik) like [[Yup'ik masks]] that represent the cosmos and earth, are incorporated into architectural elements throughout the building, such as the ceiling patterns and light fixtures.<ref name="livingstonslone"/><ref name="tuzzypiciryarait"/> The performing arts space includes a platform for [[Yup'ik dancing|dancing]] that is located under a raised ceiling designed to refer to the Yup'ik [[qasgiq]] (traditional large semisubterranean men's community house), the museum provides [[Exhibit (educational)|exhibit]] space for [[Alaska Native art]]s and crafts and support spaces and storage areas are environmentally controlled to assure proper storage of artifacts and artwork.<ref name="tuzzypiciryarait"/>
==Management== The entire facility is owned and managed by the UAF's Kuskokwim Campus, which oversees facility operations and maintenance and provides building security. The university is also in charge of renting out the facility's conference space. The multi-purpose room managed by UAF's Kuskokwim Campus. The Yup'ik Museum and gift shop operated by the Association of Village Council Presidents, Inc. (AVCP). The Consortium Library operated by the City of Bethel and the UAF.<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/><ref name="missionarea"/>
The UAF presently has a three-year grant from the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]] to increase the sustainability of this facility. The university is applying for a three-year continuation of this grant. The City of Bethel contributes to library operations. Association of Village Council Presidents controls museum space and gift shop and pays a lease of $20,000 per year.<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/>
==Multi-purpose auditorium== The multipurpose room or [[auditorium]] managed by UAF's Kuskokwim Campus, used for trainings, classes, conferences, concerts and meetings. It is the largest facility of its kind in the delta and much in demand.<ref name="missionarea"/> The multi-purpose rooms and classroom, designed for community and cultural events and conferences, are in high demand. The multi-purpose auditorium houses a stage for dance and community meetings.<ref name="livingstonslone"/>
Other events held at this facility include: weekly Saturday Markets, Cultural Nights, Summer Arts Camp (for local youth), art classes (held during the regular school year), [[Yup'ik dancing|Yup'ik dance]] nights (in which local dance groups perform for the public), and [[Athabaskan fiddle]] dances. A university representative reported that they try to schedule activities that are tied to arts and culture.<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/>
===Saturday market=== The center serves as a regional gathering center for Yup'iks to stimulate ideas, advance their [[traditional knowledge]] and [[traditional ecological knowledge]], and enhance the quality of life. The center also hosts a bimonthly summer "Saturday Market" where artisans and crafters from the [[Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta]] come to sell their crafts. There is a variety at the market, but many of the crafts include traditional Yup'ik parka cover or [[kuspuk]] (''qaspeq''), story knives (''yaaruin''), woven baskets (''mingqaaq''), [[ulu]] (semilunar woman's knife) and more. The center and local partners developed a fund based competition for start-up Yukon-Kuskokwim region businesses.<ref>[http://archives.huduser.org/oup/conferences/presentations/oupcombined/sa10/OUP2010-0420-UAFKC.pdf Yupiit Piciryarait Cultural Center, Strong Cultures Build, Strong Futures]. University of Alaska, Fairbanks Kuskokwim Campus, Bethel, Alaska</ref>
==Yup'ik Museum== The ''Yup'ik Museum'', also known as ''Yupiit Museum'' or ''Yupiit Piciryarait Museum'' is a repository of cultural heritage artifacts and art from the [[Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta]] region and is the only museum of its kind in the region of Alaska.<ref name="cubackpack">{{cite web|url=http://cubackpack.org/tag/yupiit-piciryarait-museum/|title=Yupiit Piciryarait Museum - Creighton Backpack Journalism|publisher=Cubackpack.org|accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> The museum is a tribally-owned and operated [[museum]], located inside the YPCC in Bethel.<ref name="yupikmuseum">{{cite web|url=http://bethelculturalcenter.com/home-yupiit-piciryarait-cultural-center/museum/|title=Museum|publisher=Bethelculturecenter.com|accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> The [[board of directors]] for the museum and gift shop is the Association of Village Council Presidents.<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/><ref name="missionarea"/> The museum is located within the 18,000 square foot cultural center and houses approximately 5000 pieces of art, pictures and artifacts. The areas related to the museum total 3,800 square feet and include storage, a gift shop, and offices.<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/>
The gallery houses two permanent exhibits, and one temporary exhibit that changes every 3 months.<ref name="yupikmuseum"/> The museum is free to the public, and the hours are Tuesday through Saturday, from 12 pm to 4 pm.<ref name="yupikmuseum"/> Presently, the museum and gift shop employs one part-time [[curator]]<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/>
===Museum history=== The '''Yup'ik Museum''' as the '''Bethel Museum''' got its start thanks to a $5000.00 grant awarded to the City of Bethel in 1965, as part of Alaska's Purchase Centennial, celebrating 100 years of the [[Alaska Purchase|purchase of Alaska]] from Russia.<ref name="yupikmuseum"/> The original museum was located in a log house, made with trees cut and shipped downriver from Bethel by barge. By 1968, the Bethel Council on the Arts managed the museum. The City of Bethel took over management of the museum again, and the objects were moved into a new log cabin. On July 4, 1970, it opened and was renamed the '''Yugtarvik Regional Museum'''. The log cabin was gutted by fire in 1980, damaging both the building and collection. It was broken into several times since opening and closed periodically for lack of volunteer staff. In 1995, with the opening of the new YPCC the museum was moved to AVCP and renamed the '''Yupiit Piciryarait Museum'''.<ref name="yupikmuseum"/>
===Exhibition=== The museum has three galleries. Two galleries display the permanent [[Exhibit (educational)|exhibits]] of the Yup'ik (and Cup'ik) and the [[Alaskan Athabaskans]] of the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta in ancient and contemporary times. The third gallery is reserved for temporary exhibits that changes every 3 months that include some Native collections.<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/><ref name="yupikmuseum"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alaska.org/detail/yupiit-piciryarait-cultural-center-and-museum|title=Yupiit Piciryarait Cultural Center and Museum|work=Alaska.org|accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref>
The museum has housed numerous temporary exhibits in order to stimulate cultural education and honor the lives of generations past.<ref name="cubackpack"/> The museum's first exhibit is the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s "Crossroads Alaska".<ref name="tuzzypiciryarait"/> [[Ann Fienup-Riordan]]'s ''Agayuliyararput (Our Way of Making Prayer): The Living Tradition of Yup'ik Masks'' exhibit opened in 1996 at the museum.
===Museum gift shop=== The Yup'ik Museum Gift Shop specializes in Alaska Native art work of the region and with the museum operated by the Association of Village Council Presidents, Inc. (AVCP).<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/><ref name="missionarea"/>
The ''Association of Village Council Presidents, Inc.'' (AVCP) is the recognized tribal organization and non-profit [[Alaska native corporation|Alaska Native regional corporation]] and operates the gift shop<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/> But, the [[Calista Corporation]] is a for-profit corporation business corporation and was formed at a meeting of the AVCP in Bethel on January 3, 1972, as a direct result of [[Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act]] (ANCSA) of 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calistacorp.com/sites/default/files/documents/shareholderhandbook.pdf|format=PDF|title=Calista Corporation : Shareholder Handbook|publisher=Calistacorp.com|accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> The Association of Village Council Presidents is interested in increasing the connections between this facility and the surrounding villages.<ref name="heritagecenter2005"/>
==Consortium Library== The ''Consortium Library'' is a [[library consortium]] managed in partnership among the City of Bethel, UAF and statewide library services.<ref name="missionarea"/><ref name="heritagecenter2005"/> The library incorporates the university of UAF's Kuskokwim Campus library and the City of Bethel community library, and includes a reading room overlooking a small pond, a children's reading room and a Yup'ik room which houses special collections relating to the Yup'ik culture.<ref name="tuzzypiciryarait"/><ref name="livingstonslone"/>
